comment_text: @SciShow, I know this is 5 years ago, but didn't you check? The American Chestnut is not only not extinct, it's been being bred with the Chinese species (which is where the chestnut blight came from, not Europe), to create resistant American chestnuts, which are between 95-98% Native, with the Chinese resistance genes. They're selling them NOW! Look it up. And ffs, people, BUY THEM, and PLANT THEM. They used to be the major tree species in the Eastern U.S., but y'all didn't mention that, either.

We've had spruce bark beetles in Alaska for over 50 years. We use to cut the trees they killed down for firewood when I was a kid. I can remember peeling the bark off and seeing the destruction.

Never heard the porcupines make cute little grunting noises. Of course I was making a point not to get too close.

So Kemosabe and Dennis Hopper actually both auditioned for the role of Frank Booth in Blue Velvet, because David Lynch originally intended the character to be huffing helium from the little tank he carries around in the movie. In a surprising twist, however, Lynch cast Hopper instead of Kemosabe because a helium huffing, PBR drinking porcupine was just a little too weird, even for David Lynch. =)

It seems strange to think about these beetles as - well, kind of culling the trees. I mean, one doesn't necessarily think the same way about beetles and trees as one might about, say, wolves and deer! But it makes a kind of sense, that the beetles are attacking the weaker trees. Fascinating to investigate how it is, that the insects know which trees are which; and that they're literally eating themselves out of a future, but still trying to find other trees, different hosts. Evolution in action, sort of?

How dangerous is it, all these dead trees, in regards to fire? It's drier and hotter all over, right? Does this affect the wild-fire risk for the area?

Hi SciShow team! I'm a student of forestry at the University of British Columbia, and I have to say I have not heard that 80% of BC's trees are dead, as was stated at 2:09, nor have I been able to find a source for that number. I concede that Dr. Six certainly is more informed that I am on the matter, but I suspect she may have misspoke, and meant to say that up to 80% of mature lodgepole pine in BC will be dead by the end of the MPB outbreak, which is a statistic I've seen before. MPB is undoubtedly an enormous problem here and has killed many lodgepole pine, in some regions up to 100% of them, but definitely not all trees all over BC. Not yet, anyway. MPB has begun to spread to jack pine too, which means it's heading further north into the boreal biome.
Thank you for once again shining a spotlight on the MPB outbreak. I truly believe once people start seeing the consequences of climate change as they occur, we (as a society) will be more motivated to work to fix the mistakes we humans have made.

Living in British Columbia, these little buggers have had a huge affect on us. Sawmills closing, deforestation of parks, massive forest fires aided by the dried out, dead trees, and so on. In short, they've been devastating here. Fortunately, we've been able to adapt somewhat and use some of the wood in construction projects and in material like beetlecrete. On a side note, Kemosabe is absolutely adorable!

In 1984, I spent 3 months in the eastern BC wilderness. My task was to develop a route to a potential cabin site on Mt. Coxcomb. One night, I was awakened by a repeating, grinding sound. I found a porcupine chewing its way into my heavy plywood gear storage box. I since learned it was finding the adhesives rather tasty. It had already made great inroads. I selected a stick and pushed and prodded the porcupine to go away. The porcupine was determined to stay. With some vigor, I encouraged it to leave and eventually it did. However, it wasn't done. It moved about 50 feet away and started vocalizing. For the next 6 hours, until dawn, I was serenaded with intermittent crying baby sounds and various grunts, buzzing sounds and generally disgruntled sounding porcupine complaints. I considered shooting it (after hours of not sleeping) and I checked on porcupine recipes, but my copy of "Wilderness Almanac" suggested that would have been very inappropriate as porcupines have been considered "emergency food" by First Nations people due to their relative ease of acquisition. Happily for me, it didn't return. Several years later, on a similar adventure, I made sure my box was clad in sheet metal to discourage chewing.
